Award.AwardTitle: Near Infrared Fluorescent Single Walled Carbon Nanotubes as Novel Solution Phase Optical Sensing Materials Proposal Renewal
Award.AbstractNarration: With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) and Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) Programs in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Michael Strano at Massachusetts Institute of Technology and his group will develop new chemical tools to recognize and communicate the binding of molecules to the nanotube interface using non-covalent approaches. Specifically, the investigator plans to 1) study several molecular recognition interactions through structure/property relationships of absorbed amphiphilic polymer; 2) construct a visible/near infrared dual channel single molecule imaging microscope to study molecular recognition at the nanotube surface; 3) synthesize new polymeric recognition sites based on an amphiphilic loop structure as a means of molecular recognition, such as boronic acid-poly ethylene glycol polymer brushes and a looped PEG motif; and 4) explore variants of a Ni2+ chelator-based protein recognition approach to extend to glycoprotein detection and profiling. The proposed research, if successful, will advance understanding about how chemical interfaces at the carbon nanotube surface influence exciton radiative recombination, and the learned knowledge will impact biosensing, bioimaging, as well fields beyond life science research. In addition to engaging undergraduate students in research and education, Professor Strano also proposes to disseminate research results through public media and continuously collaborate with a high school teach to broaden impacts at the K-12 level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding molecular recognition is of fundamental importance in applications such as therapeutics, chemical catalysis and sensor design. The most common recognition motifs involve biological macromolecules such as antibodies and aptamers, but these motifs are vulnerable to degradative mechanisms in the body. Here, we show that synthetic heteropolymers, once constrained onto a single-walled carbon nanotube by chemical adsorption, also form a new corona phase that exhibits highly selective recognition for specific molecules, a technique called corona phase molecular recognition (CoPhMoRe). These synthetic, non-biological antibodies show great potential as research tools for spatiotemporal measurements of neurotransmitter concentrations, the basis of medical devices that measure in vivo concentrations of biologically relevant molecules such as glucose, and a generalizable technique that can be applied to numerous macromolecules, including proteins such as fibrinogen.

 

Our work has established the use of these synthetic antibodies for the detection of neurotransmitter dopamine release. We performed molecular dynamics simulations to determine the mechanism of dopamine recognition by our nanosensors, calibrated the sensor, and monitored their response when placed under PC12 cells that release dopamine. Our most recent, and most exciting accomplishment has been in the successful detection and mapping of dopamine release from potassium-stimulated PC12 cells grown on our optical nanosensor array. Preliminary analysis suggests that cells exhibit specific release-points along their periphery, and that dopamine release is not uniform upon potassium stimulation.

 

CoPhMoRe has been extended to other biomolecules and shows great promise as a general technique for molecular recognition. Recently, we have developed a specific and selective sensor for fibrinogen, marking the first successful demonstration of CoPhMoRe for proteins. Spatiotemporal measurements of fibrinogen were able to be performed using this sensor. Previously, CoPhMoRe-based glucose sensors were developed and validated in vitro. The platform has begun to be translated to in vivo measurements, with promising results. We have been able to detect changes in glucose concentration inside of a mouse. Furthermore, significant progress has been made on the development of biosensors that distinguish between various types of saccharides as a whole.  The largest accomplishment in the carbohydrate work thus far has been the development of a sensor that detects disaccharides preferentially to monosaccharides. To the best of our knowledge, no similar sensor has been reported in the literature, which marks this sensor a significant development in characterization tools for saccharides. The extension of this work to various kinds of biomolecules has the potential to revolutionize medical diagnosis and treatment.
